1:
Do not boast about tomorrow,\q for you do not know what a day may bring.
\q
2:
Let someone else praise you and not your own mouth;\q a stranger and not your own lips.


\q
3:
Consider the heaviness of a stone and the weight of sand—\q the provocation of a fool is heavier than both.
\q
4:
There is the cruelty of rage and the flood of anger,\q but who is able to stand before jealousy?


\q
5:
Better is an open rebuke\q than hidden love.
\q
6:
Faithful are the wounds caused by a friend,\q but an enemy may kiss you profusely.

\q
7:
A person who has eaten to the full rejects even a honeycomb,\q but to the hungry person, every bitter thing is sweet.
\q
8:
Like a bird that wanders from its nest \q is a man who strays from where he lives.


\q
9:
Perfume and incense make the heart rejoice,\q but the sweetness of a friend comes from his sincere counsel.
\f + \ft Modern versions have different interpretations of this difficult verse. \f*
\q
10:
Do not forsake your friend and your friend's father,\q and do not go to your brother's house on the day of your calamity.
\q Better is a neighbor who is nearby than a brother who is far away.


\q
11:
Be wise, my son, and make my heart rejoice;\q then I will give back an answer to the one who mocks me.
\q
12:
A prudent man sees trouble and hides himself,\q but the naive people go on and suffer because of it.


\q
13:
Take a garment of one who has put up security for a stranger,\q and hold it in pledge when he puts up security for an immoral woman.
\q
14:
Whoever gives his neighbor a blessing with a loud voice early in the morning,\q that blessing will be considered to be a curse!


\q
15:
A quarreling wife is like\q the constant dripping on a rainy day;
\q
16:
restraining her is like restraining the wind,\q or trying to catch oil in your right hand.


\q
17:
Iron sharpens iron;\q in the same way, a man sharpens his friend.
\q
18:
The one who tends a fig tree will eat its fruit,\q and the one who protects his master will be honored.


\q
19:
Just as water reflects a person's face,\q so a person's heart reflects the person.
\q
20:
Just as Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied,\q so a man's eyes are never satisfied.


\q
21:
A crucible is for silver and a furnace is for gold;\q and a person is tested when he is praised.
\q
22:
Even if you crush a fool with the pestle—along with the grain—\q yet his foolishness will not leave him.


\q
23:
Be sure you know the condition of your flocks\q and be concerned about your herds,
\q
24:
for wealth is not forever.\q Does a crown endure for all generations?
\q
25:
When the hay is gone and the new growth appears,\q then the grass from the hills is gathered in for the flocks.


\q
26:
Those lambs will provide your clothing\q and the goats will provide the price of the field.
\q
27: There will be goats' milk for your food—the food for your household—\q and nourishment for your servant girls.
